title: Piers Morgan defends fat-shaming as 'tough love' after GMB guest loses 20 stone in a year
text:

Good Morning Britain host Piers Morgan defended fat-shaming on the show on Tuesday morning, calling it "tough love".

Calling out his co-star Susanna Reid for stating jibes didn't help, Piers claimed a guest on the show proved "it worked".

Darren McClintock, known as Dibsy, appeared on the show to share his story of how he went from 40 stone to 20 stone in just a year.

The food addict from Middlesbrough was warned he was eating himself to death by doctors, with his local town banning him from all takeaways to encourage him to lose weight, initiated by his personal trainer.

(Image: ITV)

Over the past year he has documented his weight loss journey, before appearing on GMB on Tuesday a year on from him taking action.

He's now lost half his body weight, a staggering 20 stone, stating the help of his town and his trainer helped him.

Host Piers shared his own experience with weight loss, suggesting that being body shamed helped him shed the pounds.

(Image: ITV)

He said, taking aim at Susanna: "Remember Susanna telling you that fat-shaming doesn't work?

"This guy was 40 stone and his entire town banned him from having takeways. Everywhere he tried to go he was on the banned list, he wasn’t allowed.

"He was fat-shamed and guess what folks, he lost half his body weight in a year. Sometimes you need someone to go, 'Hey fatty, stop eating fatty food' and by the way I'm talking as much about myself when I say that as anyone else."

(Image: ITV)

Susanna still wasn't sure it worked, admitting: "I don’t like fat-shaming to tell someone to lose weight, I think it's tough love gone a bit too far."

Dibsy and the personal trainer who saved his life then appeared on the show and actually refuted Piers' claims - claiming the technique wasn't actually fat-shaming, and was just support.

Showing off his weight loss, Dibsy added that if he had been fat-shamed he wouldn't have got through his journey with Susanna supporting his claims that he wasn't fat-shamed and that it didn't work.

(Image: ITV)

He said: "I don’t think I was fat-shamed. I describe it as being supportive, fat-shaming is being called fat."

Susanna agreed: "There is a difference between supportive advice which you consented to and cooperated with, and fat-shaming in a deliberate attempt to make someone feel bad."

Piers then slightly backtracked, admitting: "You shouldn't’t go around abusing people for being fat but I do think sometimes you do need a shock."

Dibsy is now hoping to drop down to 16 stone, while he's preparing for an operation to remove four stone of skin following his transformation.

Good Morning Britain airs weekdays at 6am on ITV.
description: Darren McClintock, known as Dibsy, was banned by his town from all takeaways before losing 20 stone in weight - but insists it wasn't fat-shaming
